refnamediv.refpurpose: Make the root file system volatile

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: systemd-volatile-root.service is a service that works on /sysroot directory. This service runs only in the initrd, before the system transitions to the host's root directory.
It is influenced by the systemd.volatile kernel command line parameter.

If systemd.volatile=yes is specified, the service will replace the root directory with a volatile memory file system (tmpfs), mounting the original (non-volatile) /usr/ inside it read-only. This way, vendor data from /usr/ is available as usual, but all configuration data in /etc/, all state data in /var/ and all other resources stored directly under the root directory are reset on boot and lost at shutdown, enabling fully stateless systems.

If systemd.volatile=overlay-root is specified, the service will overlay the root directory with an overlayfs file system, using the original /sysroot as lower layer and a writable tmpfs as upper layer. In addition, the original /usr/ is mounted inside as read-only. All files in the original file system are available, but any changes made directly under the root directory are lost on shutdown, while /usr/ cannot be modified.

If systemd.volatile=overlay-usr is specified, the service will replace the /usr/ directory with an overlayfs file system, using the original /usr/ as lower layer and a writable tmpfs as upper layer. This way, vendor data from /usr/ is available as usual, but all new modifications made under the /usr/ directory are lost at shutdown.
